description: From Middle English seaward, seward (attested only as an adjective), equivalent to sea +â€Ž -ward.

entries.meaning: Being in or facing towards the sea, as opposed to the land.
examples: The landward side of the fort faced more dangerous guns than the seaward side, which only faced what could be put on a ship.

entries.meaning: In the direction of the sea, toward the sea.
examples: Ever the sailor's widow looked seaward, hoping to see her missing man coming home.
